To test the ability of the basic model defined in Equation ( 1) to describe cell-to-cell transmission dynamics among stationary cells, we used an agent-based model (ABM) simulating viral spread in a 2D monolayer of cells. The ABM assumes cells to be distributed in a hexagonal grid, i.e., with each cell having six different neighbors, and accounts for intracellular viral replication and intercellular viral spread (see the Materials and Methods for a detailed explanation). For simplicity, proliferation and death of infected and uninfected cells were neglected. To concentrate on the dynamics of cell-to-cell transmission, we first studied infection spread by cell-to-cell transmission starting with a single infected and assuming unlimited target cell numbers. Figure 2B shows the increase in the total number of infected cells averaged over 100 individual ABM simulations that were evaluated every 24 h for 10 days.
